courses.name: HRM for Industrial Relations and HR Professionals

subjectPost.name: Work and Organizations Major: Humanities Contexts
Work and Organizations Major: Social Sciences Contexts
Work and Organizations Major: Sciences Contexts
Industrial Relations and Human Resources Major
Industrial Relations and Human Resources Specialist

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the relationship between human resource management, employment relations, and industrial relations. Extensive practical course work will expose students to the functions human resource professionals execute to recruit, select, compensate, train, and evaluate the performance of employees. The course prepares students for advanced HR topics in upper level IRE courses. Note: Course will not count towards Rotman Commerce program requirements.
cmCourseInfo.title: HRM for Industrial Relations and HR Professionals
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4.0 credits including 1.0 credit from any combination of ECO/ HIS/ POL/ PSY/ SOC with an average grade of 68% across the 1.0-credit combination. Students who do not have all of the required prerequisites are encouraged to contact the academic unit to seek a waiver.
publicationSections: Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Centre for)

cmPublicationSections.section: Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Centre for)

department.name: Centre for Industrial Relations and Human Resources

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Review the course description/restrictions before enrolling in this course.

  • ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration cancelled at any time.
  • Do not enrol in course conflicts as accommodations will not be granted.
  • Contact the Program office (IRHR@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the institutions, issues and legislation affecting the employment relationship in the public and private sectors in Canada, with emphasis on collective bargaining. The economic and political environment, history of the labour movement, union organization, certification, contract negotiation, strikes, dispute resolution, contract administration and grievances.
cmCourseInfo.title: Labour Relations
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4.0 credits including 1.0 credit from any combination of ECO/ HIS/ POL/ PSY/ SOC with an average grade of 68% across the 1.0-credit combination. Students who do not have all of the required prerequisites are encouraged to contact the academic unit to seek a waiver.
publicationSections: Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Centre for)

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the nature of organizations and the behaviour of individuals and groups within organizations, including topics such as culture and diversity, reward systems, motivation, leadership, politics, communication, decision-making, conflict and group processes. Not recommended for students in Commerce programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Organizational Behaviour
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4.0 credits including 1.0 credit from any combination of ECO/ HIS/ POL/ PSY/ SOC with an average grade of 68% across the 1.0-credit combination. Students who do not have all of the required prerequisites are encouraged to contact the academic unit to seek a waiver.

courses.name: Topics in Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Summer Abroad Program)

sections.name: LEC3001
sections.subTitle: Historical British Industrial and Cultural Influences

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics in Industrial Relations and Human Resources offered in an international setting. The content may vary from year to year. For more information check the Summer Abroad website.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Summer Abroad Program)

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics vary from year to year, but the objective of the course is to discuss current IRHR issues and their economic, legal, political and social implications.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Industrial Relations and Human Resources
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IRE244H1, IRE260H1. Additional prerequisites depending on topic.

subjectPost.name: Industrial Relations and Human Resources Major
Industrial Relations and Human Resources Specialist

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: The role of training and development initiatives in organizations. Students acquire the knowledge and skills to conduct a training needs assessment, identify training objectives, explore strategies to increase the transfer of training, design and deliver a training activity using various training methodologies, and evaluate its effectiveness.
cmCourseInfo.title: Training & Development

courses.name: Canadian Employment Law & the Non-Union Workplace (formerly IRE340Y1)

subjectPost.name: Work and Organizations Major: Social Sciences Contexts
Industrial Relations and Human Resources Major
Industrial Relations and Human Resources Specialist

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on the law governing employment in a non-unionized workplace. Specifically, it will cover every phase of the employment relationship from hiring to termination and beyond and the rights and obligations of employers and employees as developed by the Courts and under employment-related statutes (namely the Employment Standards Act, 2000 and the Human Rights Code.) The course will also cover provisions from the Occupational Health and Safety Act.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Employment Law & the Non-Union Workplace
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: IRE260H1 and 0.5 IRE/IRW credit at the 300-level
publicationSections: Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Centre for)

cmPublicationSections.section: Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Centre for)

department.name: Centre for Industrial Relations and Human Resources

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Review the course description/restrictions before enrolling in this course.

  • ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration cancelled at any time.
  • Do not enrol in course conflicts as accommodations will not be granted.
  • Contact the Program office (IRHR@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions.

Delivery Instructions

This is an online course provided asynchronously; video presentations and audio discussions of the topics will be prerecorded and posted semi-weekly. Further details will be provided by the start of the course.

courses.name: Canadian Labour Law & the Unionized Workplace (formerly IRE340Y1)

subjectPost.name: Industrial Relations and Human Resources Major
Industrial Relations and Human Resources Specialist

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on the laws impacting unionized workplaces. It will cover every phase of the Ontario Labour Relations Act, 1995 (the “LRA”) from union organizing, certification, negotiation and bargaining, collective agreement arbitration, retention of bargaining rights and decertification and termination of bargaining rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Labour Law & the Unionized Workplace
publicationSections: Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Centre for)

cmPublicationSections.section: Industrial Relations and Human Resources (Centre for)
